channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russian Critics Speak Out, Prompted by Ukraine Losses
item.description: Ukraine’s recent battlefield successes are emboldening Vladimir Putin’s critics and sending his supporters in search of someone else to blame.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A Russian tank abandoned in a village on the outskirts of Izium, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Sudden Gains Prompt New Questions for Commanders
item.description: Ukraine’s military is gauging how far its forces can press the attack, at risk of their ability to hold the new lines. Russian leaders are trying to regroup after a dramatic, demoralizing rout.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier standing atop an abandoned Russian tank near a village on the outskirts of Izium in eastern Ukraine on Sunday.

item.title: Justice Dept. Issues 40 Subpoenas in a Week, Expanding Its Jan. 6 Inquiry
item.description: It also seized the phones of two top Trump advisers, a sign of an escalating investigation two months before the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Maggie Haberman, Adam Goldman and Alan Feuer
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: The mob at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. The Justice Department has spent more than a year focused on investigating rioters at the Capitol but has more recently been issuing subpoenas to figures closer to former President Donald J. Trump.

item.title: Justice Dept. Says It’s Open to Trump’s Candidate for Special Master
item.description: Prosecutors said they would not object if Judge Raymond J. Dearie of the Federal District Court in Brooklyn is appointed to review the sensitive documents seized from Mar-a-Lago.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Leigh Vogel for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department had previously proposed two of its own choices for special master.

item.title: Senate to Investigate Charge That Trump Meddled in Prosecutor’s Office
item.description: The allegations of political motivation are in a new book by the former U.S. attorney in Manhattan, Geoffrey S. Berman.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser
item.category: Holding the Line: Inside the Nation's Preeminent US Attorney's Office and Its Battle with the Trump Justice Department (Book)
item.media:description: Allegations in Geoffrey Berman’s book will be investigated by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

item.title: King Charles Inherits Riches, and Passes Off His Own Empire
item.description: As prince, Charles used tax breaks, offshore accounts and canny real estate investments to turn a sleepy estate into a billion-dollar business.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley and Euan Ward
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles III spent years turning his royal estate into a billion-dollar portfolio.

item.title: Charles to Visit Northern Ireland Before Queen’s Coffin Arrives in London
item.description: The new monarch will continue his tour of the nations of the United Kingdom on Tuesday, before meeting his mother’s coffin at Buckingham Palace.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: King Charles III, with honor guards and other members of the royal family, holding a vigil at the coffin of Queen Elizabeth II at St Giles’ Cathedral, Edinburgh, on Monday.

item.title: ‘Succession’ Wins Best Drama at Emmys as HBO Triumphs Again
item.description: It was the sixth time in eight years that HBO has taken the television industry’s biggest prize for a recurring series. “Ted Lasso” won best comedy.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Jesse Armstrong, the creator of “Succession,” with the cast accepting the Emmy for best drama on Monday night.

item.title: ‘Squid Game’ and Lee Jung-jae Make Emmys History
item.description: The hit Korean drama won for directing, and Lee won the top dramatic acting prize, becoming the first person from a foreign-language show to win the category.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens

item.title: 2022 Emmy Winners: See the Complete List
item.description: The list of winners for the 74th annual Emmy Awards, which took place Monday night.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:description: Sheryl Lee Ralph delivered a moving speech while accepting an Emmy for best supporting actress in a comedy for “Abbott Elementary.”

item.title: How Poverty Programs Aided Children in West Virginia
item.description: For families in West Virginia, which has had especially sharp drops in child poverty over the past three decades, the shift has played out in ways not fully captured by statistics.
item.dc:creator: Jason DeParle and Maddie McGarvey
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Jackson family benefits from a safety net that has expanded significantly over the last generation.

item.title: New York Lawmakers Call for More Oversight of Hasidic Schools
item.description: After a New York Times investigation found that many of the private religious schools denied students a basic education, top officials voiced serious concerns.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro, Brian M. Rosenthal and Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The New York Times investigation found that many Hasidic schools appear to be operating in violation of state law by denying thousands of students a basic education.

item.title: In Hasidic Enclaves, Failing Yeshivas Flush With Public Money
item.description: New York’s Hasidic Jewish religious schools have benefited from $1 billion in government funding in the last four years but are unaccountable to outside oversight.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro, Brian M. Rosenthal and Jonah Markowitz
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times

item.title: Columbia University Drops From No. 2 to No. 18 in U.S. News Rankings
item.description: After doubt about its data, the university dropped to No. 18 from No. 2. But now many are asking, can the rating system be that easily manipulated?
item.dc:creator: Anemona Hartocollis
item.media:description: On Friday, Columbia said some of its data was using outdated or incorrect methodologies.

item.title: Timing Is Everything for Carlos Alcaraz
item.description: Alcaraz, the 19-year-old winner of the men’s U.S. Open, said he “worked really hard so that things like this could happen.”
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:description: Carlos Alcaraz with the U.S. Open trophy on Monday in Times Square.

item.title: Mark Finchem Says Biden Didn’t Win in 2020, and He Has Big Plans for Elections in Arizona
item.description: What happens if you follow the logic of the Republican nominee for Arizona secretary of state?
item.dc:creator: Katherine Miller
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Finchem.

item.title: Ukraine Deflates MAGA Macho Myths
item.description: Sometimes tough guys finish last. Can the right handle it?
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman

item.title: Must We Discuss the Queen and the Donald in the Same Breath?
item.description: For one thing, the job of king is already taken.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Hillbilly Elegy: A Memoir of a Family and Culture in Crisis (Book)

item.title: The Radical Constitutional Change Britain Needs
item.description: Might the queen’s death lead to unstoppable pressure for radical constitutional change, even a new British Constitution?
item.dc:creator: Linda Colley
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: The Wives of Republican Candidates Are Getting Personal
item.description: The Republican Party is under particular pressure to slap a friendly face on its nominees, with a special focus on wooing women.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Cottle
item.media:credit: Illustration by Leslie dela Vega/The New York Times; photographs, clockwise from top, by Martha Asencio-Rhine/Tampa Bay Times, via Associated Press; John Lamparski/Getty Images; Tom R. Smedes/Associated Press; Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times; Gaelen Morse/Reuters

item.title: The Killing of Eliza Fletcher Is a Tragedy, Not a Morality Play
item.description: She didn’t live and die to illustrate any point or serve a political agenda.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl
item.media:credit: Mark Weber/Daily Memphian, via Associated Press

item.title: All Biden Has to Do Now Is Change the Way We Live
item.description: The president’s legacy — and our climate future — will turn on what actually gets built, and how fast.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 2022 Ford F-150 Lightning Electric truck in production at the Dearborn Truck Plant in Michigan.

item.title: When There’s Nothing in the Fridge
item.description: Pasta, beans and more pantry cooking saves the day.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: Gentl and Hyers for The New York Times

item.title: Jennifer Egan and the Goon Squad
item.description: The novelist talks about her Pulitzer-winning book, which includes one chapter written as a PowerPoint presentation, and Stephen Fry discusses Greek mythology.

item.title: How a Marathon Win 50 Years Ago Kick-Started the ‘Running Boom’
item.description: Frank Shorter couldn’t have imagined the impact his 1972 Olympic marathon victory would have on the sport. “I was just a piece in the puzzle,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:description: Frank Shorter during the men’s marathon at the 1972 Summer Olympics.

item.title: Let’s Talk About E.L. Doctorow’s ‘Ragtime’
item.description: Join the writer Jonathan Dee in a virtual conversation on Sept. 15 about the 1975 novel.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Mother Questioned After Deaths of 3 Children Found on Coney Island
item.description: The children were found unconscious on Coney Island Beach after an emergency call early Monday morning. Their mother was discovered nearby, barefoot and “soaking wet,” the police said.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko and Chelsia Rose Marcius
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police on the boardwalk Monday.

item.title: Who Are America’s Missing Workers?
item.description: The labor market appears hot, but the share of people who are either working or actively looking for a job still hasn’t quite recovered.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis
item.media:credit: Al J. Thompson for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I could jump back in, but then I got used to being retired,” said Thomas Strait, who chose early retirement at the beginning of the pandemic.

item.title: Kenya to Inaugurate William Ruto as President, but Kenyan Television Is Mostly Shut Out
item.description: After a bitter and close election, William Ruto takes the reins of power on Tuesday. One of his team’s first moves: Limiting the access of local television outlets to the ceremony.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: President-elect William Ruto of Kenya with his wife, Rachel, in the capital, Nairobi, earlier this month.

item.title: Ramsey Lewis, Jazz Pianist Who Became a Pop Star, Dies at 87
item.description: His 1965 recording of “The ‘In’ Crowd” brought him to a place few jazz musicians reached in that era: the Top 10.
item.dc:creator: Peter Keepnews

item.title: Is Barefoot Weight Lifting Safe?
item.description: This strength training practice can fortify your feet, but experts warn that it’s not without risk.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank

item.title: Just 2 Minutes of Walking After a Meal Is Surprisingly Good for You
item.description: A new paper suggests that it takes far less exercise than was previously thought to lower blood sugar after eating.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:description: A short walk can have a significant impact on blood sugar levels.

item.title: The Joy Workout
item.description: Six research-backed moves to improve your mood
item.dc:creator: Kelly McGonigal

item.title: How Runners Can Stay Visible as the Daylight Hours Shrink
item.description: Wearing lights and reflective gear can help drivers see you when running in the dark.
item.dc:creator: Jen A. Miller

item.title: Javier Marías, to Many the Greatest Living Spanish Novelist, Dies at 70
item.description: A regular nominee for the Nobel, his books were as popular as they were lauded, filled with themes of mystery, betrayal and the moral weight of the past.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Javier Marías in 2015 in Madrid. In Spain, where his novels were greeted like blockbuster summer films, he received practically every prize available.
